bibl.title: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, May 12, 1954

div1.p: Mrs. Carroll describes the presentation of the Finlay medal at the Cuban Embassy. She discusses the behavior of her sisters-in-law before the ceremony. She does not want her sisters-in-law to know that Hench has examined James Carroll's papers.

div1.head: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, May 12, 1954
div1.opener:
May 12, 1954.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I received your letter of April 26th about the presentation at
the Cuban Embassy. I had received a telegram from them inviting me
to the ceremony, also a telephone call from the Secretary asking that I
be present to receive the medal. In the meantime, the two surviving
sisters had heard about the medal about to be presented and when I
arrived at the Embassy, they were both there and fussing between
themselves as to which one should receive it. I was rather embarrassed
because I had told the Secretary I would be there to receive the honor.
It turned out that the oldest daughter was the one to receive it but
she asked that her daughter be given the privilege in her place. The
Secretary talked with me afterwards about the matter and told how they
both had come there early and changed the plans. Being an in-law, it
seems the sisters were of the opinion I had no right to receive the
honor. It was alright with me but if I had known of the arrangements
I would not have attended for I felt left “out of the fold”. But you
know how families are about somethings. The ceremony was very nice and
I met the Ambassador and the Dr. to whom you referred and a Miss Batista
and all were very gracious to me.

One thing I could not understand, however, was why each of Dr. Reed's
children received a medal while the others got only one to a family. The
sisters-in-law were very much upset because the Ambassador said that Drs.
Handberry and Cooke were the first who voluntarily submitted to a mos-
quito bit for they said their father was the first one. So the argument
goes on and I get weary of their wrangling about it.

I was sorry to hear of your illness and that you could not attend
the ceremony but I hope you are very much improved by this time.

On April 9th, just six months and two days after losing my husband
my dear mother passed away. She was ill only fivve days and I am thank-
ful that she did not suffer too long. She was 78 but was very active and
had been down town the day she took sick. I just do not know how much a
human being can stand for it seems that I cannot go on. I am under the
Drs. care again, having a bladder infection just now which is quite
painful.

Have you had time to inquire about the foot operation we discussed
when you were here? I would like to know the approximate cost before I
would decide to make the trip to the Mayo Clinic, in the event I have
the operation done. My feet are worse than they were but I am almost
afraid to have any-thing done at my age.

I want to thank you for the book you so kindly sent me. I have not
had an opportunity to read it as I have been with my brother since my
mother's death and just returned home last week.

Please refer to the last paragraph of you letter of April 26th
saying that you had sent copies of the photographs to two or three
of the survivors of the yellow fever experiments and will let me know
what they say. I would not want you to mention to the sisters of my
husband that I let you go through those papers when you were here for
they are so opposed to letting any one see them. As I explained to
you, I am willing to cooperate and would like to have the correct
story told about their father's work but I do not have the right,
according to my lawyer, to release the papers without the written
consent of both sisters. They contend that their father got a raw
deal and that they are going to write the truth and meanwhile time
goes on and one after another passes away and nothing has been
done. I have decided not to bother any more about the matter. If
I had children, I surely would do all I could to rectify the error,
in the event there was one.

About the photographs, perhaps it would be better for you to mail
them to me so that I can put them with the other papers so that the
sisters can see them if they should visit me this summer. They did
not come to the house when they were here for the ceremony as I was
having remodeling work done and was staying with my brother in Va.
and could not accomodate them. But they warned me over and over
not to let any one have access to those papers.

You understand my position about this affair and until I get
my sanity back or some resemblance thereto, I do not want to have
any hard feelings in the family. I feel that I have had more than
my share of sorrow, having lost two loved one in six months. I
wonder what there is to this cruel old life but being a Christian,
I know that I will have to stay here until my time comes.

I forgot to tell you in discussing the ceremony that this was
the first time I had met Dr. Reed's children. I talked with them
a few minutes and they were friendly enough (in a condesending way)
but I feel that I am as good as they are even of their father got
all the fame and glory.

Thank you for your interest in letting me lnow about this
ceremony and wishing you a speedy recovery, I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Mrs. George S. H. Carroll. (Please excuse the numerous
mistakes but I am very
nervous and cannot type
well)
